issue.body: ~This changes from a header-only library to a static library.~ _Even though spdlog now offers a compiled (not header-only) build option, we keep using the header-only variant for now to smooth the transition._ --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/robotlocomotion/drake/12136)

body:
Thanks for reporting. This changed after the support for the new backtrace feature(which, if enabled, saves all messages to ring buffer for later). 

I will need  to think how to solve this and still have sensible backtrace support.

Note that for this to actually happen one need to compile with   ```SPDLOG_ACTIVLE_LEVEL``` to ```SPDLOG_LEVEL TRACE``` and then later, at runtime, change to higher log level.

```c++
#define SPDLOG_LOG_LEVEL_TRACE
logget->set_level(spdlog::level::info);
SPDLOG_TRACE(some_fun()) // won't call trace but still evaluate some_fun()
```

In any other case it won't evaluate the arguments

I've been playing around with some potential fixes locally.  Of course choosing the semantics is the first step.

My own vote would be that if the user has enabled tracing, and the compile-time LEVEL for the macro is met, then the message should be saved into the trace buffer (evaluating the macro arguments) even if the runtime log level threshold is unmet.  That seems to be like the principle of least surprise.

The naive implementation of this is to add the level + tracing check inside the CALL macro, while keeping `logger::log` unchanged (so redundantly checking), but I'm a little worried about the object code and possible performance hit.

> The naive implementation of this is to add the level + tracing check inside the CALL macro, while keeping logger::log unchanged (so redundantly checking), but I'm a little worried about the object code and possible performance hit.

Yes, that my opinion as well. Need to bench and see. If it will hurt the performance (which i doubt), a dedicated, new ```force_log``` function that doesn't check for the level can used from the macro.

FYI One other thing I noticed while playing with this locally -- it's possible that the `logger` macro argument either has side-effects or is expensive to compute.  As an enhancement, it would be nice if the macro only evaluated that argument once.

Any idea how to achive this ?
I tried this binding to some variable: 
```c++
#define SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL(logger, level, ...) do {\
    auto &eval_logger = logger;\
    if(eval_logger->should_log(level) || eval_logger->should_backtrace()) \
        eval_logger->log(spdlog::source_loc{__FILE__, __LINE__, SPDLOG_FUNCTION}, level, __VA_ARGS__);\
    } while(0)
``` 
but got compiler errors about r values.
```console

In file included from /home/gabi/spdlog/tests/includes.h:17,
                 from /home/gabi/spdlog/tests/test_macros.cpp:5:
/home/gabi/spdlog/tests/test_macros.cpp: In function ‘void ____C_A_T_C_H____T_E_S_T____0()’:
/home/gabi/spdlog/include/spdlog/spdlog.h:304:73: error: cannot bind non-const lvalue reference of type ‘spdlog::logger*&’ to an rvalue of type ‘spdlog::logger*’
 #define SPDLOG_DEBUG(...) SPDLOG_LOGGER_DEBUG(spdlog::default_logger_raw(), __VA_ARGS__)

```

My attempt went like
```c++
#define SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL(logger, level, ...) do { \
    spdlog::logger* spdlog_logger_temporary_detail = logger; \
    if(spdlog_logger_temporary_detail->foo()) \
        spdlog_logger_temporary_detail->bar() \
} while (0)
```

We have to be a little bit careful about the variable name, since I believe some compilers will warn if a macro-introduced variable shadows an existing local.

I didn't try to use `auto` since I believe we are OK to presume the logger is-a `spdlog::logger`, and that any compiler optimization related to the concrete subclass would still happen even with the upcast to the base.
Does it compile when you pass to the macro a ```shared_ptr<logger>``` instead of raw?

Good point.  I think the solution is to take your proposal and add a const (see below).  It's the pointer that is const, not the pointed-to object that is const, so we can still call the non-const `log` method, and it gets us reference lifetime extension so should work in all cases.

```c++
#define SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL(logger, level, ...)                            \
  do {                                                                    \
    const auto& SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL_capture_logger = logger;               \
    if (SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL_capture_logger->should_log(level) ||           \
        SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL_capture_logger->should_backtrace()) {          \
      SPDLOG_LOGGER_CALL_capture_logger->log(                             \
          spdlog::source_loc{__FILE__, __LINE__, SPDLOG_FUNCTION}, level, \
          __VA_ARGS__);                                                   \
    }                                                                     \
  } while (0)
```

The "evaluate even with logging is off" regression is already fixed on the v1.x branch, but has not yet been tagged for https://github.com/gabime/spdlog/releases as 1.4.3.  So, you could build from the branch if you need the fix ASAP.  Personally I'm just using 1.3.1 until a new tag is cut.

@jwnimmer-tri and @MuwazanaSA After much consideration, I decided to remove this feature -  It adds 2  additional checks and increases the size and complexity of the generated code.

* Most use cases don't need the redundant checks of the log+traceback levels. 
* It is only applicable when when ```SPDLOG_ACTIVE_LEVEL``` is high enough and one of the args is a costly computation expression
* In cases that it is relevant, It can be easily solved by wrapping with ```if(logger->should_log(debug)) SPDLOG_LOGGER_DEBUG(...)```.
Understood, thanks.  I can just add the macro my users want into my downstream project directly, instead of relying on spdlog to provide it natively.
